body: As far as I can tell, reqwest doesn't implement the standard Unix convention of using the `http_proxy` and `https_proxy` environment variables to specify a proxy URL. This is a blocker for migrating my application from direct use of hyper, which manually implements this convention using `with_http_proxy()`.

issue.title: Upgrade openssl dependency
issue.body:
Currently, Hyper's [Cargo.toml](https://github.com/hyperium/hyper/blob/master/Cargo.toml) specifies using [Rust-OpenSSL](https://github.com/sfackler/rust-openssl) version `0.7.x`.  At the time of this writing, the [latest release](https://github.com/sfackler/rust-openssl/releases) is version `0.8.2`, which includes a number of bug fixes that, [in some applications](https://github.com/mattnenterprise/rust-ftp/pull/51) has resolved some functional failings.

I'd like to ask for Hyper to adopt these changes and upgrade to the latest version.

body: Well, at the very least if reqwest had something like `with_http_proxy` then the application using reqwest could set the proxy (eg via [env_proxy](https://crates.io/crates/env_proxy) like rustup does). Of course reqwest could *also* have a convenience method to read the env vars and set the proxy accordingly.

Yes, that's what we currently do - we manually get the proxy URL from the environment and use the url crate to extract the necessary components for `with_http_proxy()`. (Thanks for the link to env_proxy, I might have to start using that!)

As such, an equivalent to `with_http_proxy()` would be really, really helpful.

> curl offers the ability to make an exclude list for proxies, where any URL in the list skips using a proxy. Is this very useful, or sufficiently niche enough that people can just use 2 Clients?

It's a bit niche, but I'm sure it would make life easier for people, particularly if it implements the `no_proxy` environment variable as per curl.

I'm evaluating rust, and I wanted to test reqwest but without proxy support it's not very usefull in my case.

All the use cases you listed are important. Exclude list are niche indeed, but they might as well be implemented to support PAC files.

I would add to your list :

- Support automatic proxy settings on Windows through WinINET or WinHTTPÂ calls.
- Support PAC files. This is not easy as it's a javascript file, but would be tremendous.

issue.title: Is there a way to use a unix socket?

labels.name: B-rfc
labels.description: Blocked: Request for comments. More discussion would help move this along.

labels.name: C-feature
labels.description: Category: feature. This is requesting a new feature.

labels.name: S-waiting-on-author
labels.description: Status: waiting on author to provide more info, or do more work.

repository.name: reqwest
repository.description: An easy and powerful Rust HTTP Client

issue.body:
I would like to do the equivalent of:
```
curl --unix-socket /var/run/docker.sock http://localhost/containers/json
```

There's the [unix_socket crate](https://crates.io/crates/unix_socket) but I'm not sure if I can use it with reqwest.

body: @seanmonstar I also don't think Reqwest should read envvar... that's something that apps should handle, not libraries. I don't even think there should be a convenience API to read such. It should be easy enough to do this in those apps, once the API for using proxies is added.

issue.title: Update hyper to 0.10 from 0.9

repository.name: gitlab-api-rs
repository.description: Rust wrapper to the GitLab API.

issue.body:
Hyper 0.10 [was released](https://github.com/hyperium/hyper/releases/v0.10.0) 20 days ago.

According to the release notes:

> hyper will no longer provide OpenSSL support out of the box. The `hyper::net::Openssl` and related types are gone. The `Client` now uses an `HttpConnector` by default, which will error trying to access HTTPS URLs.
> 
> TLS support should be added in from other crates, such as hyper-openssl, or similar using different TLS implementations.
> 
> **If using a client, take a look at [reqwest](https://crates.io/crates/reqwest).**
> 
> If using a server, look at [hyper-native-tls](https://crates.io/crates/hyper-native-tls) or [hyper-openssl](https://crates.io/crates/hyper-openssl).
> 
> ([2f48612c](https://github.com/hyperium/hyper/commit/2f48612c7e141a9d612d7cb9d524b2f460561f56))

While the SSL update is interesting (that would certainly simplify compilation on OSX, see for example #1), it is suggested to change to reqwest.

Unfortunately, reqwest does not yet support proxy (see [discussion here](https://github.com/seanmonstar/reqwest/issues/30)). Until it can be used with a proxy, we'll be stucked at hyper 0.9.

issue.title: Replace custom download crate with reqwest
issue.body:
reqwest is mature enough that I don't feel the need to keep maintaining an abstraction layer, and would rather be using pure Rust instead of curl.

Make sure that it continues obeying the relevant environment variables for setting up proxies.

Some headers should be removed when redirecting to a different domain:

- Cookie
- Authorization

issue.body:

This is a step toward fixing https://github.com/seanmonstar/reqwest/issues/15

body: Any movement on this? This is also blocking me from using reqwest instead of hyper.

Proxies can currently be configured to intercept HTTP, HTTPS, and all
requests. HTTPS tunneling is supported.

Closes #30
